message_1:
Suppose you intercept the Hill cipher encrypted message "OLK" using the 2x2 matrix key 
$\begin{bmatrix} 3 & 5 \\ 7 & 4 \end{bmatrix}$.
Decode the message using Hill cipher Cryptanalysis methods.
message_2:
To decode the message "OLK" using the Hill cipher with the given 2x2 matrix key, we first need to find the inverse of the key matrix. 

The key matrix is:
$\begin{bmatrix} 3 & 5 \\ 7 & 4 \end{bmatrix}$

To find the inverse of a 2x2 matrix, we can use the formula:

$A^{-1} = \frac{1}{\text{det}(A)} \begin{bmatrix} d & -b \\ -c & a \end{bmatrix}$

where $A = \begin{bmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{bmatrix}$ and det(A) is the determinant of matrix A.

The determinant of the key matrix is:

$\text{det}(A) = ad - bc = (3)(4) - (5)(7) = 12 - 35 = -23$

Since we are working with the 26 letters of the alphabet, we need to find the modular inverse of the determinant. In this case, we need to find a number x such that:

$-23x \equiv 1 \pmod{26}$

We can find that the modular inverse of -23 is 9:

$-23 \cdot 9 \equiv 1 \pmod{26}$

Now, we can find the inverse of the key matrix:

$A^{-1} = \frac{1}{\text{det}(A)} \begin{bmatrix} d & -b \\ -c & a \end{bmatrix} \pmod{26}$

$A^{-1} = 9 \begin{bmatrix} 4 & -5 \\ -7 & 3 \end{bmatrix} \pmod{26}$

$A^{-1} = \begin{bmatrix} 36 & -45 \\ -63 & 27 \end{bmatrix} \pmod{26}$

$A^{-1} = \begin{bmatrix} 10 & 7 \\ 1 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$

Now that we have the inverse key matrix, we can decode the message "OLK". First, we need to convert the letters to their corresponding numerical values (A=0, B=1, ..., Z=25):

O = 14
L = 11
K = 10

Since we have a 2x2 key matrix, we need to divide the message into 2-letter blocks. In this case, we have only one block: "OL".

Now, we multiply the inverse key matrix by the numerical values of the message block:

$\begin{bmatrix} 10 & 7 \\ 1 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 14 \\ 11 \end{bmatrix} \pmod{26}$

$\begin{bmatrix} 10(14) + 7(11) \\ 1(14) + 1(11) \end{bmatrix} \pmod{26}$

$\begin{bmatrix} 140 + 77 \\ 14 + 11 \end{bmatrix} \pmod{26}$

$\begin{bmatrix} 217 \\ 25 \end{bmatrix} \pmod{26}$

$\begin{bmatrix} 3 \\ 25 \end{bmatrix}$

Now, we convert the numerical values back to letters:

3 = D
25 = Z

So, the decoded message is "DZ".
